channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Colombia Peace Deal Is Defeated, Leaving a Nation in Shock
item.media:description: Supporters of a peace agreement that had been years in the making watched referendum results on Sunday in Bogotá, Colombia.
item.description: Voters narrowly rejected an agreement, signed just days before by the president and rebel leaders, that would have ended the country’s 52-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: JULIA SYMMES COBB and NICHOLAS CASEY
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: For Mahmoud Abbas, a Gesture. For Critics, a Betrayal.
item.description: Attending Shimon Peres’s funeral has brought heavy backlash to Mr. Abbas from within his own party, across social media and in the Palestinian streets.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and RAMI NAZZAL

item.title: Pope Francis Notes Azerbaijan’s Religious Tolerance, Not Rights Abuses
item.description: The pope focused on diplomacy in meetings with leaders of other faiths, and the nation’s president, later expounding on other topics, like advice for American Catholic voters.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Outrage Over Fish Kill in Vietnam Simmers 6 Months Later
item.media:description: Protesters in Taipei, Taiwan, demonstrated in August against a chemical spill that killed tons of fish and that was attributed to the Formosa Ha Tinh Steel Corporation, a Taiwanese company.
item.description: Thousands of demonstrators swarmed a steel factory in Ha Tinh Province over the weekend, echoing the street protests in the country’s major cities in April.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Spaniards, Exhausted by Politics, Warm to Life Without a Government
item.media:description: A supporter holding a poster of Pedro Sánchez, who stepped down as the leader of the Socialist Party, outside a party meeting in Madrid on Saturday.
item.description: All year, Spain has plodded along without an elected national government. For some Spaniards, this is a wonderful thing. “No government, no thieves,” one said.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER and DAVID ZUCCHINO

item.title: Hungary Votes Against Migrants, but Too Few to Clear Threshold
item.media:description: Migrants walking to a camp in Horgos, Serbia, last week. Hungary has already built a fence to stem the migrant flow.
item.description: The result gave the country’s autocratic prime minister, Viktor Orban, a partial victory, though what Mr. Orban plans to do now remained a mystery.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Jeroen Oerlemans, Dutch Journalist, Is Killed by ISIS Sniper in Libya
item.media:description: Jeroen Oerlemans, a Dutch photojournalist.
item.description: Mr. Oerlemans, who had once been taken hostage by Islamist extremists in Syria, was killed while covering the front line of a battle in Surt.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Robert Mugabe Seizes on the Latest Political Threat to His Zimbabwe: WhatsApp
item.media:description: The Rev. Evan Mawarire held the Zimbabwean flag and sang the national anthem in July before addressing his supporters in Johannesburg.
item.description: The Zimbabwean government, which had dismissed social media until a viral plea led to large protests, raised prices on cellphone data as internet use has swelled in the country in recent years.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Britain, Seeking to Mitigate ‘Brexit’ Turbulence, Hints at Economic Shift
item.media:description: Philip Hammond, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, at the International Convention Center in Birmingham, England, on Monday.
item.description: The chancellor of the Exchequer promised to take “whatever steps are necessary to protect this economy” as the country prepares to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Russia Withdraws From Plutonium Disposal Treaty
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin in Moscow last month. He signed a decree on Monday pulling Russia out of a plutonium disposal treaty.
item.description: Citing a “radically changed environment” of hostility and threats, President Vladimir V. Putin abrogated a 2000 pact on the disposal of plutonium.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Jakarta Journal: What’s Clogging Jakarta’s Waterways? You Name It
item.media:description: An excavator getting trash out of a river in Jakarta, Indonesia, in August. The city is dredging its 17 rivers and canals — the first time it has done so since the 1970s.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Indonesia’s capital is working to dredge its network of rivers and canals, long blocked with garbage and a central contributor to chronic flooding.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Montreal Bans New Ownership of Pit Bulls After Fatal Mauling
item.media:description: The final vote by the Montreal City Council was 37 to 23 in favor of the ban on pit bulls.
item.description: Critics of the new rules say the dogs are being unfairly singled out, and a lawsuit has been filed against the regulations.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Yoshinori Ohsumi of Japan Wins Nobel Prize for Study of ‘Self Eating’ Cells
item.media:description: Yoshinori Ohsumi of Japan used baker’s yeast to identify genes essential for autophagy.
item.media:credit: Akiko Matsushita/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.description: A cell biologist, Dr. Ohsumi was recognized for his work on autophagy, the process by which cells recycle their content.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Sinosphere: The Cultural Revolution in Tibet: A Photographic Record
item.media:description: Tsering Woeser’s father, an officer in the People’s Liberation Army in Lhasa when the Cultural Revolution broke out in 1966, photographed many public attacks on Tibet’s old ruling class and religious leaders. Here, a Buddhist nun wears a sign labeling her as a counterrevolutionary.
item.description: The writer Tsering Woeser interviewed people who appeared in photographs her father, a People’s Liberation Army officer, took during the upheaval.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING

item.title: Suspects in Russian Politician's Killing Plead Not Guilty
item.description: Five men suspected of involvement in the killing of opposition leader Boris Nemtsov pleaded not guilty on Monday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Taliban Fighters Again Enter Northern Afghan City of Kunduz
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard during fighting between Taliban militants and Afghan security forces in Kunduz, Afghanistan, on Monday.
item.media:credit: Bashir Khan Safi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The militants, who briefly overran the city last year, attacked from four directions before dawn. Fighting was continuing, and residents were trying to flee.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: Shantou Journal: Fate Catches Up to a Cultural Revolution Museum in China
item.media:description: Visitors at the Cultural Revolution Museum in Shantou, China, in August. The museum was covered up in the spring, a few weeks before the 50th anniversary of the start of the Cultural Revolution.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: A memorial site, a labor of love and loss that took decades to open, has been covered with propaganda posters and shut down after 11 years.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Duterte, Philippines’ Leader, Apologizes to Jews for Holocaust Remark
item.description: President Rodrigo Duterte, who had said he would be “happy to slaughter” his country’s three million drug addicts, said his apology was intended only for Jews.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Talks Will Start by End of March, Theresa May Says
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain at BBC studios in Birmingham, England, on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The prime minister’s timeline, the most detailed so far, could set the stage for Britain to leave the European Union by spring 2019.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Purchases of U.S. Companies Have Some in Congress Raising Eyebrows
item.media:description: Wang Jianlin, chairman of the Wanda Group, hopes to buy at least a 50 percent stake in one of the “Big Six” Hollywood studios.
item.description: Sixteen members of Congress are raising questions over the foreign acquisition of American movie theaters and studios.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)

item.title: What in the World: Need to Land a Plane? In Australia, They Break Out the Toilet Paper
item.description: For the Royal Flying Doctor Service to arrive and land on a remote runway at night, about 30 cans with flaming rolls sometimes have to be lined up.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: What in the World: Lousy Libidos: Why Do Pandas Have So Little Sex?
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; photo by Enmyo/Shutterstock
item.description: Pandas have a slim window each year for mating, but even then, they often don’t know what to do, so scientists have taken to offering them guidance.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Problem With the Islamic Apocalypse
item.media:description: An Islamic State mural in Shirqat, Iraq, last month.
item.description: Too many Muslims, not just radicals, believe that the end times are near. They should instead focus on this lifetime.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: News Analysis: 15 Years in the Afghan Crucible
item.media:description: Residential apartments in a gated community in Kabul.
item.description: After 15 years of American military involvement, there are glimmers of a better future despite the enduring threat of the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Opinion: Shimon Peres: Not Just a Man of Peace
item.media:description: Shimon Peres 1998.
item.description: In Israel, the late president is best known for his contributions to the military, not for the Oslo agreement.
item.dc:creator: TOM SEGEV

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
